meanings.definition: To become accustomed to a new climate or environment.
meanings.sent1: After moving to the mountains, it took some time for the family to acclimate to the thin air.
meanings.sent2: The tropical plants had to acclimate to the colder weather when winter arrived.
meanings.sent3: The penguin tried to acclimate to the desert but quickly realized it was a bad idea.
meanings.sent4: She felt like a fish out of water, trying to acclimate to the fast-paced city life.
meanings.sent5: The astronaut had to acclimate to the lack of gravity in space, which was a strange sensation.

meanings.definition: To adjust or adapt to a new situation or surroundings.
meanings.sent1: Starting a new job can be challenging as you acclimate to the different responsibilities.
meanings.sent2: The rescue dog needed time to acclimate to its new home and family.
meanings.sent3: The robot had to acclimate to working alongside humans, which was a unique experience.
meanings.sent4: She had to acclimate to the idea of living in a foreign country before making the big move.
meanings.sent5: The young bird had to acclimate to flying on its own, but soon soared through the sky with confidence.
